case_name: N. E. Horo v. Smt. Jahan Ara Jaipal Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 909 of 1971 filed under section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 909 of 1971. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1971 of the Patna High Court in Election Petition No. 2 of 1970.

facts.text: Patna High Court judgment and order dated May 21, 1971 in Election Petition No. 2 of 1970 held that nomination papers of respondent Smt. Jahan Ara Jaipal Singh were illegally rejected by Returning Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1971 of the Patna High Court in Election Petition No. 2 of 1970. Frank Anthony, A. T. M. Sampath and E. C. A Agrawala, for. the appellant.

facts.text: Election of Shri N.E. Horo from 51 Khunti Parliamentary Scheduled Tribe Constituency in Bihar was set aside by Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Patna High Court holding that the numberination papers of the respondent Smt. Jahan Ara Jaipal Singh had been illegally rejected by the Returning Officer. For that reason the election of the returned candidate Shri N. E. Horo from the 51 Khunti Parliamentary  Scheduled Tribe  Constituency in the State of Bihar was set aside.

facts.text: Election Commission issued notification on May 1, 1970 for by-election in Khunti Parliamentary Constituency due to death of late Shri Jaipal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On May 1, 1970 the Election Commission of India issued a numberification calling upon the above-named Parliamentary Constituency to elect a Member to the Lok Sabha in the vacancy caused by the death of late Shri Jaipal Singh.

facts.text: Last date for filing nomination papers was May 8, 1970; scrutiny on May 9, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for filing the numberination papers was May 8, 1970. The date for scrutiny was May 9, 1970.

facts.text: Respondent Smt. Jahan Ara Jaipal Singh filed two nomination papers as Congress candidate.

anchor.surface_text: Several persons filed numberination papers including Theodore Bodra and others. Two numberination, papers were filed on behalf of the respondent who was a Congress  Ruling  candidate for the aforesaid by-election.

facts.text: Respondent claimed to be widow of late Shri Jaipal Singh and member of Munda Scheduled Tribe.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent she was the widow of late Shri Jaipal Singh and was a member of the Munda Scheduled Tribe in the State of, Bihar. She filed certain certificates to that effect.

facts.text: Theodore Bodra filed objection to respondent's nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: Bodra filed an objection petition to the numberination papers of the respondent.

facts.text: Returning Officer rejected respondent's nomination papers after hearing arguments.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer, after hearing arguments, passed an order rejecting the numberination papers of the respondent. The numberination papers of all the other candidates were accepted.

facts.text: Shri N.E. Horo declared elected on June 3, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: After the polling took place, the result of the election was announced on June 3, 1970 and the appellant Shri Horo was declared elected to the Lok Sabha.

facts.text: Election petition filed by respondent on July 8, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: On July 8, 1970 the respondent filed an, election petition.

facts.text: Petitioner (respondent in appeal) stated she was Tamil by birth, married late Shri Jaipal Singh in 1954 according to Munda customs.

anchor.surface_text: In para 4 of the petition it was stated that the petitioner was a Tamil by birth. She married late Shri Jaipal Singh in the year 1954 according to the rights and rituals of Mundas in the presence of Parha Raja, Parha Munda, Parha Pahan, relatives of the deceased and the members of the Tribe at Morabadi a Mohalla of Ranchi.

facts.text: Marriage ceremonies performed according to Munda custom: washing of wife's feet, feast of male goat meat and Handia, new name Lankashri given.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 5 the ceremonies which were performed according to Munda custom were mentioned. These ceremonies inter alia were the washing of the wifes feet by the elder sister of the husband and the holding of the feast of the male goat meat and drinks of Handia etc. A new name was given by her mother-in-law to the petitioner, that name being Lankashri.

facts.text: Returning Officer held that status of Munda could be acquired only by birth, not by marriage.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Returning Officer that the status of a Munda companyld be acquired only by birth and number by marriage and that the petitioner did number belong to the Munda Scheduled Tribe was challenged principally on the ground that the Returning Officer had number companysidered the custom by which if a Munda male marries a women number belonging to Munda Tribe and that is accepted by the Tribe the wife acquires the membership thereof.

facts.text: Returned candidate denied marriage according to Munda custom and that non-Munda can become Munda by marriage.

anchor.surface_text: In his written statement the returned candidate Shri Horo maintained that even though the election petitioner might be iving as wife of late Shri Jaipal Singh she was never married in accordance with the custom of the Munda Tribe prevalent in Chhota Nagpur. It was denied that she was ever accepted as a member of the Munda companymunity as numbersuch custom is prevalent in that companymunity.

facts.text: Lok Sabha dissolved on December 27, 1970; High Court on January 14, 1971 held election petition not infructuous.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the election petition the Lok Sabha was dissolved on December 27, 1970. A petition was filed before the High Court on behalf of Shri Horo that the election petition should be dismissed as having become infructuous. The companyrt made an order on January 14, 1971 holding that the election petition companyld number be dismissed on that ground.

facts.text: High Court found factum of marriage not disputed; controversy on whether wife acquired tribe membership.

anchor.surface_text: On the main issues, namely  2  and  3  it was expressly stated in the judgment that the factum of the marriage of the elec- tion petitioner with the late Shri Jaipal Singh had number been disputed. The real companytroversy between the parties in the High Court centered round the point whether the marriage was in such form that the wife acquired the membership of the Tribe.

facts.text: High Court held respondent married according to Munda custom and accepted as member of Munda tribe.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt also companysidered the various authoritative books and other works relating to the Mundas and came to the companyclusion that on a survey of the entire, evidence and the circumstances there was numberreason to discredit the evidence which had been led on behalf of the petitioner that she was married according to the Munda custom and that it was with the approval and sanction of the Tribe that she had been accepted as a member of the Munda tribe.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court finding that respondent belongs to Munda tribal community by marriage approved by Parha Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: Even without invoking the doctrine of domicile the respondents marriage with late Shri Jaipal Singh who was a Munda having been approved and sanctioned by the Parha Panchayat of the Munda tribe it can be said that she became a me mber of the Munda tribal companymunity.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and it is dismissed but in view of the nature of the points involved we leave the parties to bear their own companyts in this Court.

facts.text: Respondent was Christian by religion but claimed Munda tribe membership via marriage.

anchor.surface_text: In the election petition it was stated inter alia that the petitioner  who is number respondent before us  was the widow of Late Shri Jaipal Singh and belonged to the Munda Scheduled Tribe although she was a Christian by religion.

facts.text: Petitioner averred Munda customary law allows wife to acquire tribe membership if marriage accepted by tribe.

anchor.surface_text: It was averred in paragraph 3 of the petition that according to the Munda Customary Law when a Munda male married outside the Munda Tribe if his marriage is accepted by the Tribe he companytinues to be a member of that Tribe and his wife also acquires its membership.

facts.text: Theodore Bodra was Chairman of Bihar Legislative Council.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the Returning Officer had been influenced by Bodra who was the Chairman of the Bihar Legislative Council.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no corrupt practice alleged against Bodra under s.123(7) RPA.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly satisfied that numberallegation of any companyrupt practice had been made in the election petition against Bodra and therefore he was number a necessary party within S. 82 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent divorced, decree absolute on May 6, 1954; married Jaipal Singh May 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The first was that the respondent who was a Christian by birth, was a divorcee and according to her own statement the decree nisi in the divorcee proceedings had been made absolute on May 6, 1954. According to her she got married to late Shri Jaipal Singh on May 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Is the election petition maintainable ? Whether the petitioner was the legally married wife of late Shri Jaipal Singh according to the custom of Munda Tribe prevalent in Chhota Nagpur ?

issues.text: Whether the petitioner was the legally married wife of late Shri Jaipal Singh according to the custom of Munda Tribe prevalent in Chhota Nagpur?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the petitioner was the legally married wife of late Shri Jaipal Singh according to the custom of Munda Tribe prevalent in Chhota Nagpur ? Whether the petitioner could legally acquire the status of a Munda by virtue of her marriage to late Shri Jaipal Singh and whether she had been accepted as a member of the Munda Tribe by the said Tribe ?

issues.text: Whether the petitioner could legally acquire the status of a Munda by virtue of her marriage to late Shri Jaipal Singh and whether she had been accepted as a member of the Munda Tribe by the said Tribe?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the petitioner could legally acquire the status of a Munda by virtue of her marriage to late Shri Jaipal Singh and whether she had been accepted as a member of the Munda Tribe by the said Tribe ? It may be mentioned that so far as issue No. 1 was concerned the objection taken was that the election petition was defective on account of the non-joinder of necessary parties.

issues.text: Whether the allegations made against Bodra in the election petition amount to a corrupt practice under section 123(7) of the Representation of the People Act?

anchor.surface_text: For finding out what a corrupt practice is we have to turn to s. 123 of the Act. According to Mr. Anthony the allegations made against Bodra fell within sub-s. 7 of s. 123 which is in the following terms S. 123 The following shall be deemed to be corrupt, practices for the purposes of this Act--

issues.text: Whether the allegations made against Bodra in the election petition amount to undue influence under section 123(2) of the Representation of the People Act?

anchor.surface_text: sub- s. 2 of S. 123 the relevant part of which is as follows Undue influence, that is to say, any direct or indirect interference or attempt to interfere on the part of the candidate or his agent, or of any other person with the consent of the candidate or his election agent with the free exercise of any electoral right

issues.text: Whether the strict rule of endogamy of the Munda tribe has been deviated from and whether custom has sanctioned such deviation?

anchor.surface_text: The question that has to be enquired into is whether the strict rule of endogamy of the Munda tribe has been deviated from and whether custom has sanctioned such deviation. D. N. Mazumdar in his work Races and Cultures of India deals with tribal organisations in Chapter 17.

issues.text: Whether the marriage of the respondent to late Shri Jaipal Singh was a nullity under section 57 of the Indian Divorce Act due to remarriage within six months of the decree absolute?

anchor.surface_text: This marriage was a nullity as under s. 57 of the Indian Divorce Act 1869 she could not enter into a second marriage until after the expiry of six months from the date the decree had been made absolute.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 25 of the written statement it was asserted that a non-Munda merely by virtue of the marriage with a Munda could not ipso facto become a Munda. If a person was not born of a father belonging to a Scheduled Tribe he or she could not legally claim to be a member of the said Tribe.

arguments.claim: Election petition not infructuous despite Lok Sabha dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: The court made an order on January 14, 1971 holding that the election petition could not be dismissed on that ground.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: opponents. It was alleged that the Returning Officer had been influenced by Bodra who was the Chairman of the Bihar Legislative Council. The decision

holdings.text: No allegation of any corrupt practice under s.123(7) of the Act was made against Bodra as there was no suggestion that he influenced the Returning Officer for the furtherance of any candidate's election prospects.

anchor.surface_text: plain reading of the above paragraph shows that no such allegation was made that Bodra had influenced the Returning Officer I-L887 Sup CI/72 for the purpose mentioned in S. 123 7  of the Act. The essential ingredient of that provision is to obtain, procure etc. by a candidate of any assistance  other than the giving of a vote  for the furtherance of the prospects of that candidates election from any person in service of the Government and belonging to the classes mentioned in the sub-section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of para 21 of election petition shows absence of essential ingredient of procuring assistance for candidate's prospects; rule application to statutory definition.

holdings.text: The allegation in para 21 does not amount to undue influence under s.123(2) as there is no interference or attempt to interfere with the free exercise of any electoral right.

anchor.surface_text: It is not possible to comprehend how the allegation contained in para 21 can be understood to amount to a suggestion of direct or indirect interference, or attempt to interfere on the part of the candidate etc. with the free exercise of any electoral right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of allegation fails to match statutory elements of undue influence; no interference with electoral right.

holdings.text: No allegation of any corrupt practice had been made against Bodra; therefore he was not a necessary party under s.82(b) and the election petition is maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly satisfied that no allegation of any corrupt practice had been made in the election petition against Bodra and therefore he was not a necessary party within S. 82 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of corrupt practice allegations means no requirement to join under s.82(b); s.86 dismissal not attracted; upholds High Court.

holdings.text: The point regarding nullity of marriage under s.57 of Indian Divorce Act cannot be agitated as it was not raised before High Court, no pleadings or issues framed thereon.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first point it was never canvassed or argued before the High Court. No plea was taken by Shri Horo in the written statement that there could be no valid marriage between the respondent and late Shri Jaipal Singh owing to the provisions contained in s. 57 of the Indian Divorce Act 1869 until after the lapse of. a period of six months from the date the decree of divorce was made absolute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: no pleadings, issues, evidence before lower court; cannot raise first time in Supreme Court.

holdings.text: The respondent was legally married to late Shri Jaipal Singh according to Munda custom; factum of marriage not disputed and ceremonies proved.

anchor.surface_text: On the main issues, namely  2  and  3  it was expressly stated in the judgment that the factum of the marriage of the elec- tion petitioner with the late Shri Jaipal Singh had not been disputed. ... that she was married according to the Munda custom and that it was with the approval and sanction of the Tribe that she had been accepted as a member of the Munda tribe.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding on evidence of ceremonies and witnesses upheld; no reason to discredit petitioner's evidence.

holdings.text: Custom exists allowing deviation from endogamy; Munda male's marriage to non-Munda approved by Parha Panchayat admits wife as member of Munda tribal community.

anchor.surface_text: Even without invoking the doctrine of domicile the respondents marriage with late Shri Jaipal Singh who was a Munda having been approved and sanctioned by the Parha Panchayat of the Munda tribe it can be said that she became a me mber of the Munda tribal community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from witnesses, anthropological texts prove custom of acceptance via Parha Panchayat despite endogamy; wider connotation of 'tribal community' under Art.342 includes assimilated by marriage.

holdings.text: The term 'tribal community' has a wider connotation than 'tribe'; includes non-tribal woman married to tribal with panchayat sanction.

anchor.surface_text: It can well be said that the term tribal community has a wider connotation than the expression tribe. A person who, according to the strict custom of a tribe. cannot be regarded as a member of that tribe may well be regarded as a member of that tribal community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of Art.342 and Scheduled Tribes Order; analogy to domicile; social changes allow assimilation.

holdings.text: No cogent reasons to disagree with High Court findings on marriage and tribal membership; Returning Officer's rejection of nomination illegal.

anchor.surface_text: We do not find cogent or weighty reasons for disagreeing with the view of the High Court on the points under discussion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full consideration of evidence, books, witnesses supports High Court; upholds setting aside election.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and it is dismissed but in view of the nature of the points involved we leave the parties to bear their own costs in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings uphold High Court judgment.

precedents.citation: V. V. Giri v. D. Suri Dora Others 21 E. T. R. 188

anchor.surface_text: In V. V. Giri v. D. Suri Dora Others 1  one of the, questions raised, was whether respondent No. 1 in that case had ceased to be a member of the Schedule Tribe at the material time because be had become a Kshtriya. This companyrt observed that it  1  21 E. T. R. 188.

precedents.case_name: V. V. Giri v. D. Suri Dora
precedents.cited_proposition: in a tribe which is endogamous birth alone can confer the status of membership of the tribal community
precedents.cited_holding: status came to be based on birth alone. a person who belonged by birth to a depressed caste or tribe would find it very difficult, if not impossible, to attain the status of a higher caste amongst the Hindus by virtue of his volition, education, culture and status

precedents.citation: Wilson Reads v. C. S. Booth A. T. R 558 Assam 128

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further relied on the decision in Wilson Reads v. C. S. Booth 1  in which it was held that the question whether a person can be regarded as a member of the Khasi tribe was a question of fact depending upon the evidence produced in the case. It was said that the whole object of reserving a seat for a particular tribe was to afford the companymunity, is a whole, a right of representation and therefore the question of the membership of a particular individual of that companymunity companyld number be companysidered divorced from the very object of legislation. Thus the companyduct of the companymunity which had been given the right of special representation. the manner and how the A. T. R 558 Assam 128

precedents.case_name: Wilson Reads v. C. S. Booth
precedents.cited_proposition: question whether a person can be regarded as a member of the tribe is a question of fact depending upon the evidence produced and the conduct of the community
precedents.cited_holding: the conduct of the community which had been given the right of special representation, the manner and how the community regarded a particular individual and whether the community as a whole intended to take the individual within its fold were all matters which would be relevant

As regards the first point it was never canvassed or argued before the High Court. In the result this appeal fails and it is dismissed but in view of the nature of the points involved we leave the parties to bear their own costs in this Court.
